I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Government of Viet Nam has requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to 
provide technical assistance (TA)1 to support implementation of the State-Owned Enterprise 
Reform and Corporate Governance Facilitation Program.2 The ADB strategy toward the state-
owned  enterprise  (SOE)  sector  in  Viet  Nam  has  two  defining characteristics:  (i)  long-term 
support, and (ii) responsiveness. ADB has been engaged with SOE reform since the late 1990s. 
ADB’s  country  strategy  and  program,  2007–20103 as  well  as  the  proposed  new  country 
partnership strategy, 2012–2015 underline SOE reform as central to its strategy for business 
development and private-sector-led employment growth. The ADB country assistance program 
evaluation4 carried out in 2009 also recommends support for SOE reform. A fact-finding mission 
was  fielded  on  26–30  September  2011  and  reached  an  understanding  with  government 
counterparts on the objective, scope, cost, and implementation arrangements for the TA. The 
design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  To date, efforts at SOE reform in Viet Nam have largely focused on equitization (the 
process of converting SOEs into joint stock companies with limited liability) and divestment of 
small and medium-sized SOEs. While this has resulted in a marked reduction in the number of 
SOEs,  remaining  SOEs—many  of  them  large  in  size,  complex  in  operation,  and  weak  in 
performance—continue to account for some 40% of assets in the enterprise sector.5 Reform 
and restructuring of large SOEs will be crucial to reducing the deadweight of inefficient state 
production,  promoting  private  sector  development,  and  supporting  economic  growth.  Such 
reforms, however, will be inherently complex in both design and implementation, involving a 
disparate range of stakeholders and interests. 
 
3.  The government clearly recognizes the necessity as well as the complexity of these 
reforms and has undertaken a step-by-step approach in partnership with ADB through the 
implementation of a multitranche financing facility (MFF) in support of SOE reform (footnote 2). 
The MFF supports the corporate, operational, and financial restructuring of selected individual 
SOEs on a pilot basis—with a view to supporting the development of a generalizable approach 
to reform and restructuring of large SOEs. 
 
4.  The MFF became effective in 2011 and has a projected implementation period of about 
5 years. The overall MFF amount is for $630 million ($600 million ordinary capital resources; 
$30 million Asian Development Fund), with the first tranche (periodic financing request [PFR 1]) 
amounting  to  $130  million  ($120  million  ordinary  capital  resources;  $10  million  Asian 
Development Fund) currently under implementation. Earlier project preparatory TA approved in 
2006 supported the preparation of the overall MFF design as well as PFR 1.6 It closed in 2009 
following  completion  of  these  objectives.  Additional  resources  will  be  needed  to  support 
implementation of the MFF (including the design and preparation of remaining tranches) and

5.  PFR 1 supports the pilot testing of a systematic approach to SOE reform involving the 
corporate, financial, and operational restructuring of two selected SOEs.7 Before moving into 
PFR 2, it will be important to closely monitor progress on the ground of the two participating 
SOEs under PFR 1, and provide support for ongoing stakeholder consultation and consensus 
building with respect to reforms. Ongoing monitoring and assessment of the pilot reforms will 
also allow for refinements to be made to the approach adopted under PFR 1 for subsequent 
tranches. The Ministry of Finance (MOF), the executing agency, has been assigned by the 
government to take the lead in the development and implementation of an SOE restructuring 
program, which takes into account and builds on lessons and experience gained from the 
implementation of the pilot restructurings under the MFF. This TA aims to provide support to the 
MOF and other implementing agencies in this regard through support for the updating of the 
institutional and policy framework to allow for an effective generalizable approach to SOE 
restructuring and reform, drawing on lessons from the implementation of the pilot restructurings 
under the MFF. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
6.  The impact of the TA will be improved efficiency and accountability of the SOE sector. 
To this end, it will support, as its outcome, the adoption of an updated institutional and policy 
framework for SOE reform, based on lessons from implementation of pilot restructurings under 
the MFF. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
7.  Development of a generalizable approach to SOE reform will involve close monitoring 
and ongoing assessment of the pilot restructuring efforts under PFR 1 of the MFF, with a view to 
supporting ongoing stakeholder consultation and consensus building on the approach adopted. 
To this end, the TA will provide support through (i) establishment of a monitoring system for 
assessing progress on SOE reform and restructuring; (ii) development of an updated approach 
to SOE restructuring building on lessons learned from implementation of the program; and (iii) 
development of knowledge products and related capacity to update the institutional and policy 
framework for SOE reform. The TA will also help to support the government in the identification 
and preparation of SOE candidates for subsequent restructurings. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
8.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,200,000 equivalent. The government has requested ADB 
to finance $1,200,000 equivalent. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s Technical 
Assistance Special Fund (TASF-IV). The government will provide counterpart support in the 
form of counterpart staff, office space and utilities, and other in-kind contributions. The cost 
estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
                                                
7  Debt restructuring has been undertaken and contracts for the main corporate restructuring packages for the two 
SOEs have been awarded with implementation expected to commence in early 2012.

3 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
9.  The MOF will be the executing agency for the TA. Implementing agencies include the 
Ministry of Planning and Investment and SOEs undergoing restructuring. Coordination will make 
use of existing project management units and arrangements established under the MFF. Inputs 
provided by participating government agencies and SOEs will include provision of necessary 
counterpart staff time, facilities, documents, and data. 
 
10.  The TA will be implemented over 24 months from February 2012 to January 2014. The 
majority of activities under the TA will be carried out by an international consulting firm with 
strong experience in SOE reform. Activities under the TA will be divided into two components: 
one focused on monitoring and evaluation of pilot restructuring and supporting strengthening of 
the policy and institutional framework for SOE reform, and the other focused on supporting MFF 
implementation.  The  international  consultants  supporting  activities  related  to  monitoring, 
evaluation, and strengthening of the institutional and policy framework will comprise (i) an SOE 
reform and corporate governance specialist (8 person-months), (ii) a corporate restructuring 
specialist (3 person-months), and (iii) a legal and regulatory specialist (2 person-months). Two 
national consultants will support the international experts: (i) an SOE reform and corporate 
governance  specialist  (5  person-months),  and  (ii)  a  legal  and  regulatory  specialist  who  is 
familiar with SOE reforms (1.5 person-months). International consultants supporting activities 
related  to  MFF  implementation  will  include  (i)  SOE  reforms  and  governance  specialist  (5 
person-months),  (ii)  corporate  restructuring  specialist  (3  person-months),  (iii)  financial 
restructuring specialist (2 person-months), and (iv) a SOE legal and regulatory expert (1 person-
month). The team will be supported by the required number of national consultants (5 person-
months), including a project coordinator. Interpreters will be engaged to facilitate the workshops. 
The  consulting  firm  will  be  engaged  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of 
Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time) using the quality- and cost-based selection 
method based on submission of simplified technical proposals. 
 
11.  This will be complemented by a small team of national individual consultants to provide 
support to the project monitoring unit within the MOF. The team will consist of one national 
consultant (minimum 15 person-months) familiar with the Viet Nam SOE sector as well as an 
interpreter (24 person-months) to help in translation and related work. A number of workshops 
will be held intermittently to strengthen the capacity of the line ministries, the MOF, and the 
Ministry of Planning and Investment; and to discuss, comment, and obtain stakeholder feedback 
on the evolving framework for SOE reform. Workshops will engage national and international 
resource persons as needed. Consultants will be engaged in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines 
on the Use of Consultants. TA disbursements will be done in accordance with ADB’s Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). All procurement will 
be done in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to 
time). 
 
12.  TA  implementation  will  be  closely  monitored  and  evaluated  through  (i)  ongoing 
consultations with stakeholders, (ii) regular review missions, and (iii) periodic progress reports. 
The  TA  will  support  timely  distillation  and  dissemination  of  recommendations  and  lessons 
through (print as well as web-based) publication of working papers and support for stakeholder 
workshops and conferences).

4   
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
13.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,200,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Viet Nam for Strengthening Support for State-Owned Enterprise Reform and 
Corporate Governance Facilitation Program, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Component 1: Monitoring, Evaluation, and Institutional Strengthening 
 
1.  International Consultants 
1.  State-owned enterprise reform and corporate restructuring expert (team leader) 
(international, 8 person-months). The main tasks include the following: 
(i)  In  consultation  with  other  experts  and  stakeholders,  develop  a  knowledge 
communications plan identifying knowledge products to be developed under the 
technical assistance (TA) along with a plan for dissemination. Products may 
include,  but  not  necessarily  be  limited  to,  case  studies,  policy  notes,  and 
guidelines. 
(ii)  In  collaboration  with  other  experts,  prepare  knowledge  products  and  other 
background papers in support of TA activities. 
(iii)  Develop a monitoring and consultation plan for each pilot restructuring project 
based on identification of key issues, milestones, and indicators; and provide 
ongoing monitoring of restructuring process based on  the plan and in close 
consultation with key stakeholders. Based on the above work, develop a set of 
monitoring  indicators  (both  financial  and  nonfinancial)  for  the  state-owned 
enterprise (SOE) sector. Prepare periodic assessment reports on the progress of 
pilot restructurings, including ongoing identification of implementation issues and 
lessons learned. 
(iv)  Support conduct of workshops, as needed, to understand stakeholder concerns 
and build and maintain support for reforms. 
(v)  Review the ongoing restructuring process being undertaken by the two pilot 
projects under the first tranche to evaluate the adequacy and effectiveness of the 
restructuring approach adopted under the State-Owned Enterprise Reform and 
Corporate Governance Facilitation Program, identifying lessons learned.1 
(vi)  Support review and refinement of the selection criteria and approval process for 
SOE  candidates  for  restructuring,  in  close  consultation  with  the  Ministry  of 
Finance (MOF) and the Asian Development Bank (ADB). 
(vii)  Support the design of a self-financing mechanism for the assessment of SOE 
candidates for restructuring, in close consultation with the MOF and ADB. 
(viii)  Prepare  periodic  financing  request  (PFR)  design  assessments,  identifying 
relevant  lessons  from  the  implementation  of  the  current  PFR(s)  and 
recommending changes to the design of the subsequent PFR(s). 
(ix)  Provide for distillation and dissemination of lessons learned from individual pilot 
restructurings into recommendations for a generalizable approach to SOE reform 
and restructuring. 
(x)  Develop a code of corporate governance to be followed by the SOE sector. In the 
application of such a code of governance identify the need, if any, to develop 
sector-specific governance codes. 
(xi)  Provide for the identification of other key issues relevant to SOE reform, based 
on  stakeholder  consultation/experience  from  multitranche  financing  facility

2.  Corporate operational and financial restructuring specialist (international, 3 person-
months).  The  specialist  will  have  extensive  working  knowledge  of  general  corporation 
restructuring, in particular in operational and financial aspects. The main tasks include the 
following: 
 
(i)  In coordination with the SOE reform expert (team leader) and the legal and 
regulatory expert, the specialist should review the ongoing restructuring process 
being undertaken by the two pilot projects under the first tranche to evaluate the 
adequacy  and  effectiveness  of  the  restructuring  approach  adopted  and 
identifying lessons learned. 
(ii)  In  the  process,  make  a  detailed  evaluation  of  the  effectiveness  of  both  the

(iii)  Promote dialogue with policy makers and other stakeholders, and identify and

(iv)  In coordination with the corporate operational and/or financial restructuring expert

(vi)  In collaboration with the team leader and other experts, support the preparation

related proposal for SOE restructuring (including provision of comments of the 
MOF’s restructuring proposal).

3.  Support for the Project Monitoring Unit 
 
6.  National financial  expert  (one, minimum 15 person-months) and interpreter (one, 
24 person-months). A national financial consultant familiar with the SOE sector in Viet Nam will 
be engaged to support the project monitoring unit within the MOF to monitor the implementation 
of the SOEs that are undergoing restructuring under the program. In coordination with the 
consulting team, the consultant will develop the format for periodic progress reports and monitor 
their submission. The interpreter should be a graduate with a good command of the English 
language and help the MOF in the translation of all documents related to the SOE program as 
well  as  assist  the  MOF  in  meetings.  The  interpreter  will  also  be  the  official  translator  in 
workshops that will be held under the TA. 
 
B.  Component 2: Multitranche Financing Facility Implementation 
1.  International Consultants 
7.  State-owned enterprise reform and corporate governance specialist (international, 
5 person-months). The main tasks include the following:

(i)  In coordination with the consultants under component 1, the government and 
ADB agree on the selection criteria for candidates for subsequent restructurings. 
(ii)  Identify and short-list general corporations requiring financing under the program 
to undertake the equitization (the process of converting SOEs into joint stock 
companies with limited liability)  and listing process. 
(iii)  With  the  help  of  the  corporate  restructuring  specialist  and  the  financial 
restructuring  specialist  as  well  as  national  consultants,  conduct  an  overall 
assessment  of  the  selected  general  corporations,  including  their  financial 
restructuring plans, legal mandates, board and management, financial status, 
and business plans for the next 5 years to determine the required financial and 
technical support. 
(iv)  Identify the technical inputs for the selected general corporations covering tasks 
leading  to  overall  restructuring,  including  (a)  undertaking  financial  valuation; 
(b) defining the overall business strategy; (c) reforming organizational structures 
to  improve  corporate  governance,  operational  efficiency,  reporting,  and 
transparency; and (d) recommending a specific set of measures to introduce and 
implement solid corporate governance standards. 
(v)  Define methodologies for project monitoring and achievement of objectives for 
the program. 
(vi)  Hold workshops and other meetings with various stakeholders to ensure effective 
policy dialogue dissemination and consensus building. 
 
8.  Upon selection of additional candidates for participation under the multitranche financing 
facility, the expert will do the following: 
 
(i)  Assess the financial management capabilities of selected general corporations; 
review and verify cost information provided by the selected general corporations. 
(ii)  Build  a  financial  model,  using  Excel,  to  assess  the  impact  of  the  proposed 
tranche project on the borrowing general corporations’ financial positions. 
(iii)  Identify key risks and their impact, documented through cash flow sensitivity 
analysis. 
 
9.  Corporate restructuring specialist (international, 3 person-months). The main tasks 
include the following: 
 
(i)  In coordination with the SOE reform and corporate governance specialist/team 
leader, identify select general corporations that could be considered for support 
under the program. 
(ii)  Conduct an overall assessment of the selected general corporations, including 
their legal mandates, board and management status, and business plans for the 
next 5 years to determine the appropriate operational restructuring process and 
required technical support. 
(iii)  Develop approaches, methods, techniques, and timing of the selected general 
corporations’ organizational/managerial restructuring and redefining of strategic 
directions. 
(iv)  Define areas that could be considered for support under the program, such as 
improving organization, management, responsibility, performance reporting and 
transparency, and enhancing corporate governance standards. 
 
10.  Financial restructuring specialist (international, 2 person-months). The main tasks 
include the following:

12  Appendix 3 
 
 
 
(i)  In  coordination  with  the  SOE  reform  specialist/team  leader,  identify  select 
general corporations that could be considered for support under the program. 
(ii)  Conduct an overall assessment of the selected general corporations, including 
their financial status, and business plans for the next 5 years to determine the 
required financial and technical support for their financial restructuring, possibly 
for equitization and stock listing. 
(iii)  Develop approaches, methods, techniques, and timing of the equitization and 
assessment of the selected general corporations, if appropriate, including (a) a 
review of equitization options and procedures, (b) valuation, and (c) preparation 
of master plans. 
(iv)  Support the team leader in developing a modality for providing market-based 
financial and technical support to financial restructuring of the selected general 
corporations under the program, with a clear set of selection criteria. 
 
11.  State-owned enterprise legal and regulatory expert (international, 1 person-month). 
In coordination with the team leader, the expert will ensure the proposed restructuring process 
for the selected SOEs is consistent and in conformity with the domestic legal provisions, and 
identify any regulatory impediments for selected SOEs to go through the restructuring. 
 
2.  National Consultants 
 
12.  State-owned  enterprise  reform  and  corporate  restructuring  specialist  (national, 
5 person-months), corporate finance specialist (national, 3 person-months), and SOE legal 
and regulatory expert (national, 1 person-month). The main tasks include the following: 
 
(i)  Provide  support,  as  needed,  to  respective  international  experts  under 
component 2 in the conduct of their tasks, including the collection and analysis of 
information and translation of technical information and/or outputs into English 
and/or Vietnamese as needed. 
(iii)  Conduct research on specific topics as required by ADB and the international 
experts. 
 
C.  Workshops 
 
13.  All  consultants  will  support  the  conduct  of  a  series  of  stakeholder  workshops  to 
disseminate the results of their work and further SOE reform. The workshops will be designed 
and organized in consultation with the government and the MOF.
